data.title: What Is the Best Place To Live in Utah in 2024?
data.meta_description: Home to five national parks, Utah is the perfect home base for outdoor lovers. See what else the best places to live in Utah have to offer.
data.text:
Home to five national parks, Utah is the perfect home base for outdoor lovers. See what else the best cities in Utah have to offer.

By Livability on November 21, 2023

Are you interested in moving to Utah? The Beehive State is home to more than 3.3 million people across 29 counties, but this state’s highlight reel is less about the statistics and more about the landscape. The temperate and dry climate means you can indulge in all kinds of outdoor recreation through the entire year, ranging from cycling, swimming and hiking in summer to skiing, snowboarding and snowshoeing during the winter season. Five national parks are located within the state, which aids in the state’s vibrant economy and jobs that run the gamut from cattle ranching and mining to technology and health care.

Logan

Why is Logan a great place to live in Utah?

Nestled among the beautiful Rocky Mountains, Logan, Utah is a city north of the state capital that offers an abundance of scenic views, outdoor recreation and educational opportunities. It is home to Utah State University (USU), a popular institution that offers a variety of programs in specialties such as agriculture, engineering, business and education. While the school’s presence understandably attracts a number of students, the city is also rich in performing arts, dining and local shopping. Young families often find themselves drawn to this growing city because of its steady economic growth with job opportunities in industries like health care, manufacturing and education.

Newcomers are often pleasantly surprised by the reasonable cost of living in Logan. Groceries and restaurants are in line with the national average, but mortgage costs and rental rates are generally lower than you would expect to pay in comparable cities around the country.

Read more about living in Logan, UT.

Ogden

Why Ogden is a great city in Utah.

Ogden, Utah has developed quite a reputation for its historic architecture, sweeping landscapes and association with Weber State University. Paired with its easy access to a wealth of outdoor recreation in the nearby Wasatch Mountain range and proximity to world-class ski resorts like Snowbasin and Powder Mountain, it’s easy to understand why people are flocking to this growing city north of the state capital.

If you’re concerned about the cost of living in an area so rich with outdoor recreation and modern amenities, fear not. Ogden is known for having a more affordable cost of living than other larger cities in Utah, which makes it attractive to young professionals and families looking to get their foot in the door of homeownership. The affordability doesn’t mean you have to compromise on activities either. There are several family-friendly amenities in the city, such as parks and playgrounds, as well as galleries, museums and a host of festivals and events that cater to residents of all ages.

Read more about living in Odgen, UT.

Orem

Why is Orem a great place to live in Utah?

Tucked in the northern region of Utah County and named after Walter C. Orem of the Salt Lake and Utah Electric Interurban Railroad, Orem, Utah is part of the Provo-Orem metropolitan area just south of Salt Lake City. Living here offers several advantages, especially if you’re a student. Orem is home to Utah Valley University (UVU), an increasingly popular choice among students throughout the state and surrounding region, and is just a short drive from the well-known Brigham Young University.

Given its association with major educational institutions, you can expect to find a lot of students, professors and administration living in the area. But you won’t be outnumbered if education isn’t the reason you want to put down roots here. The city has a reputation for being family-friendly and provides a convenient location near the stunning Wasatch Mountains and all the outdoor activities it has to offer, such as hiking, skiing, mountain biking and camping. Residents of all ages can also enjoy a vibrant arts and culture scene, and a wealth of local coffee shops, restaurants and craft breweries. With amenities like these, it’s easy to see why Orem is not only one of the bset places to live in Utah, it’s also among the Top 25 Best Places To Live Out West.

Read more about living in Orem, UT.

Park City

Why Park City is a great place to live in Utah.

Known for its stunning beauty and popular location in the mountains, Park City, Utah is nestled in the northern part of the state and is rich in outdoor recreational opportunities. The area has become a sought-after destination for locals and visitors alike due to its renowned skiing and snowboarding in the winter and mountain biking, fly fishing and hiking in the summer. It’s also home to three major ski resorts: Park City Mountain Resort, Deer Valley Resort and Canyons Village.

Living in Park City comes at a price. Some estimates suggest that the average cost of living in Utah is around $34,000, while Park City comes in closer to $42,000 by comparison. The host of luxury housing and vacation rentals mean housing costs are higher than most other cities in the state, but many residents find that the resort atmosphere and its countless amenities justify the expense. After all, living here means you don’t have to go far at all to take advantage of year-round outdoor recreation, as well as world-class dining, shopping and a multitude of annual events and festivals.

Read more about living in Park City, UT.

Provo

Why Provo is a great city in Utah

Located around 43 miles south of Salt Lake City, Provo, Utah is the third largest city in the Beehive State and known for being home to Brigham Young University. This iconic research university is owned by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (LDS) and is one of the largest private religious universities in the country. The school plays a significant role in the city’s culture and economy (it’s considered one of the best college towns in the country), with several attractions tied to the Mormon faith as well as employment opportunities at the school. You can also find a surprising number of technology jobs thanks to the area’s growing reputation as the “Silicon Slopes.”

As far as activities are concerned, life here won’t leave you bored. The outdoor recreation is unparalleled, and there truly is something for everyone regardless of skill level. Bridal Veil Falls is a local favorite with options to hike up to the waterfall or enjoy the view from the base. Provo River Parkway Trail offers walking, biking and jogging opportunities. You can even hop in the car and simply enjoy the stunning views of the canyon, river and mountains along the Provo Canyon Scenic Byway.

Read more about living in Provo, UT.

Salt Lake City

Why Salt Lake City is a great city to live in Utah.

Salt Lake City, Utah, is surrounded by breathtaking natural landscapes, such as the towering Wasatch Mountains and nearby national parks like Zion, Bryce Canyon and Arches. This understandably makes it a haven for outdoor enthusiasts who want to take advantage of the year-round opportunities for hiking, mountain biking, skiing and snowboarding. Recent years have seen an increasingly diverse and growing economy, as well. This is particularly true in the tech arena, which is why Salt Lake City and its surrounding cities are often called the “Silicon Slopes.”

The city is deeply associated with The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (LDS), but it still has a lot to offer non-members. Salt Lake City hosts numerous festivals and cultural events throughout the year, and you can find a wealth of museums, live musical and theatrical performances, and top-notch restaurants and breweries. The University of Utah is downtown, as well as a variety of parks, playgrounds and other attractions that have made the city increasingly attractive to young families. Salt Lake City often lands on Livability’s annual list of the Best Places To Live in the U.S.

Read more about living in Salt Lake City, UT.

Sandy

Why is Sandy a great city to live in Utah?

Sandy, Utah provides a convenient blend of suburban comfort and outdoor recreation, making it an attractive place to put down roots if you want to live in Salt Lake City without paying downtown prices. The city is located within the Salt Lake Valley, just south of Salt Lake City, and offers easy access to major highways and, consequently, many neighboring cities. The housing market is influenced by the city, but you can find a pleasant mix of single family homes, townhomes and apartments for reasonable prices compared to other comparable cities around the country.

Outdoor recreation is a huge draw for new residents. Sandy is surrounded by the stunning Wasatch Mountains, which provide year round entertainment in the form of hiking, biking, skiing, snowshoeing, boating, fishing and other water sports. The district is also known for its quality schools and plenty of employment opportunities, which make it an appealing home for young professionals, growing families and those wanting to retire in an area that has plenty of leisure activities.

Read more about living in Sandy, UT.

St. George

Why St. George is a great place to live in Utah.

Retirees often flock to St. George, Utah, due to its favorable climate, outdoor recreation and reasonable cost of living compared to other popular retirement destinations. While it does offer a lot of opportunities for seniors to soak up the sun and make the most of their golden years, this beautiful city also attracts young professionals and families with its ample sunshine, educational opportunities and low crime rates.

Tourism is an important part of the economy and culture of St. George, and for good reason. The city’s proximity to natural wonders such as Zion National Park, Bryce Canyon National Park and Grand Canyon National Park make it an excellent home base for anyone wanting to explore multiple parks on an extended vacation. The city itself also has hiking, biking and horseback riding trails, as well as a wealth of iconic red rock formations that are popular with rock climbers.

Read more about living in St. George, UT.

Interested in Moving to Utah?

Choosing where to live in Utah doesn’t have to be hard. We have more resources for moving to Utah as well as other best places to live in the West. No matter where you want to be, we can help you decide where to move and learn about other best places to live in the U.S.

Other Great Places to Live Near Utah
